definition: A binding application plan. If a student is accepted ED, they must withdraw all other applications and attend that college. Students can only apply to one college ED.

A non-binding application plan. Students apply early and receive a decision early (typically in December or January), but they are not obligated to attend. They have until the national decision day (May 1) to make their choice.
The standard application plan with a winter deadline (typically January 1st or 15th). Decisions are released in the spring (typically March or April). It is non-binding.
An application plan where colleges review applications as they are received, rather than waiting for a single deadline. This is common at many large public universities.
A standardized online application portal used by over 900 colleges. Students fill out one main application and can submit it to multiple schools.
An alternative online application portal used by over 150 colleges. It offers a 'digital locker' for students to collect materials throughout high school.

A college's policy that students are not required to submit SAT or ACT scores. If a score is submitted, it will be reviewed. This is different from 'Test-Blind,' where scores are not reviewed even if submitted.
A letter written by a teacher or counselor that assesses a student's academic performance, intellectual curiosity, and character for a college application.

A waiver that allows a student to apply to a college without paying the application fee. Qualification is based on financial need, such as being on the free/reduced lunch program or having an SAT/ACT fee waiver.

term: FAFSA (Free Application for Federal Student Aid)
definition: The official form that students and families must fill out to apply for federal financial aid, including grants, loans, and work-study. It opens in December (formerly October 1st).
